title: 110_hr6225
content: The "Improving SCRA and USERRA Protections Act of 2008" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends equity powers in title 38 of the United States Code. Section 3 introduces relief for students who are members of the armed forces during their military service. The "Improving SCRA and USERRA Protections Act of 2008" provides tuition and reenrollment benefits for servicemembers called to military service. Institutions of higher education must refund tuition and fees for uncompleted education and offer reenrollment opportunities with the same academic status. The term 'institution of higher education' refers to a 2-year or 4-year institution as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Student debts incurred by servicemembers enrolled in full-time education at an institution of higher education are exempt from creditor protection based on income level. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. The amendments provide tuition, reenrollment, and student loan relief for postsecondary students called to military service. The effective date for these changes is after the enactment of the section. Additionally, servicemembers are granted the ability to terminate or suspend certain service contracts entered into before a permanent change of station or deployment orders. A person in military service can terminate or suspend a contract at any time after receiving military orders. The suspension of the contract continues for the duration of the person's deployment. Service providers cannot charge suspension or termination fees, except for a nominal fee for suspension. The person in military service can defer payment of any equipment fees during deployment. For cellular or telephone service contracts, they can keep the same number after the suspension ends. This section applies to various services such as water, electricity, and internet access. The person in military service can terminate or suspend contracts for services like video programming, internet access, water, electricity, oil, gas, or other utilities if they receive military orders for deployment or a change of permanent station. Termination or suspension requires written notice and a copy of military orders to the other party. Termination or suspension of service contracts by a servicemember can be done through various methods such as hand delivery, private carrier, facsimile, or mail with return receipt requested. The effective date of contract termination is when the notice is delivered, and the service provider cannot impose early termination fees. Under the contract, early termination or suspension charges are not allowed for servicemembers. Any unpaid obligations or liabilities at the time of termination must be settled by the servicemember. Fees paid in advance for services after termination must be refunded within 60 days. The relief granted to the servicemember can be modified by the court if deemed necessary for justice and equity. The penalties for violating the contract include fines of up to $5,000 for individuals and $10,000 for organizations. The remedy provided is in addition to other available legal remedies, including consequential or punitive damages. Military personnel can seek equitable relief if they believe the contract has been violated. The person in military service can take legal action to stop violations or seek damages equal to three times the amount owed. If awarded damages, they are entitled to attorney fees and court costs. Definitions for this section are provided for clarity. Definitions for the section include terms like multichannel video programming service, Internet access service, cellular telephone service, and telephone exchange service. The term 'telephone exchange service' is defined under section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. SEC. 308 and SEC. 309 address termination or suspension of service contracts and extension of protections to dependents. SEC. 5 imposes penalties for violating interest rate limitations under the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act. Section 207 of the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act introduces penalties for violations, with fines up to $5,000 for individuals and $10,000 for organizations. Servicemembers have the right to seek equitable relief through legal action if they believe a creditor is violating the Act. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act allows servicemembers to bring legal action against creditors for violations, seeking damages equal to three times the interest charged plus interest. The court determines the number of violations by counting each servicemember obligation with proper notice as a single violation. The Servicemembers Civil Relief Act allows servicemembers to take legal action against creditors for violations, seeking damages equal to three times the interest charged plus interest. If awarded damages, servicemembers are entitled to costs of the action and reasonable attorney fees. These rights and remedies are in addition to any other available under the law. Servicemembers can seek damages under the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act, including consequential or punitive damages. SEC. 6. GUARANTEE OF RESIDENCY FOR SPOUSES OF MILITARY PERSONNEL. Guarantee of Residency: Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to ensure that individuals accompanying their military spouse out of state do not lose their residency for voting purposes. Amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to protect residency for individuals accompanying military spouses out of state. SEC. 705 amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to guarantee residency for military personnel and spouses. SEC. 7 amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to ensure that a spouse of a servicemember does not lose or acquire residence for tax purposes when complying with military orders. SEC. 8 amends the Servicemembers Civil Relief Act to specify that a spouse's compensation during military service is not considered income for tax purposes if the spouse is not a resident of the jurisdiction where the servicemember is serving. Passed the House of Representatives on July 31, 2008. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
